One thing I notice you're bad at is failing fast during debugging sessions. You tend to get overconfident every time you think you've found the cause of an issue and then immediately shift to "done" mode, running the full test suite, merging your work, etc. But often you're wrong about the root cause and you're wrong about having fixed the issue and because you jumped to "done" so fast you often waste a huge amount of time running the entire test suite instead of doing quick, targeted test cycles. You ought to validate your work in as time-efficient a way as possible to reduce the cycle time between hypothesis and test result.
let's continue debugging but remember to try to fail fast, ok?
how is this failing fast, again? you keep getting this wrong.
3 minutes is too long a loop. fail faster
continue. remember to fail fast. never allow any task to run more than 45 seconds.

I want you to actually execute all 133 files individually. If you want you can do them in batches of 5-10. As soon as you find a test that fails, hangs, or is too slow (more than 15 seconds is too long), flag it, quit the test run, fix that specific test, and then rerun the file.

ok here's your assignment. I want you to work in that worktree for the duration of this session. I want you to act as an orchestrator agent farming out work to a group of task agents. The task agents will each get a set of files and be asked to get the tests in those files passing. Here's the catch: you need to maintain a checkout system. Only one agent is allowed to write to a given file at a given time. And only one agent globally can run any tests at a time, even if they're in different files. I want you to create temp files to track all of this and then I want you to get to work. OK? 

CRITICAL: you are never allowed to run the full test suite all at once. only in chunks that can be completed in 45s. enforce this 45s limit by issuing a "sleep 45 && echo" command just before you invoke pytest. 

ANy questions?

I'd like you to function as an orchestrator for the duration of this session. You are managing this software project and we are currently on a largescale tech debt paydown initiative. here's what I want you to do:
- use the TODO file to keep track of all the outstanding tech debt tasks. if you encounter untracked tech debt, create a new task for it and put it in the TODO file, appropriately prioritized.
- avoid doing any work directly yourself: farm everything out to task agents, as much as possible.
- follow the prescribed workflow protocol for this project, including using worktrees.
- after each agent is done with a task, I want you to mark that task for review. there can only be one reviewer agent at a time, and that reviewer agent's job is to run the full test suite against the worktree with the work being reviewed, fix any bugs, identify any code quality issues, and and then merge to main once all the tests are passing.
- you can spin up up 4 task agents at a time. 

CRITICAL: This is a tech debt and bug hunting initiative. No failing tests, no tech debt left behind. Be thorough and perfectionistic. If you can't fix a problem immediately, document it.

The current project is in rough shape. I've surfaced a ton of tech debt and broken features in the past few days. I would like you to do an extremely thorough review of the codebase, looking for tech debt and bugs. You are not allowed to make any writes or run any tests. This is a read-only exercise. When you're done please check your findings against the TODO file and let me know what you've discovered that's new.

I have a strategic problem that I'd like to talk through with you. If you look in the TODO file you'll find a very large backlog of bugs. My machine can handle running up to 6 agents in parallel, but my test infrastructure only supports one agent running tests at a time. What I'd like is to create a workflow that kept six agents running constantly. Some of them would be doing actual coding work, some would be reviewers. The reviewers would be responsible for assessing completed but unmerged tasks for task completion and code correctness, merging main into the worktree's feature branch, resolving any conflicts, and then running the full test suite before merging. There needs to be zero tolerance for failing tests. Again only one agent can run tests at a time. How could I support this workflow so that claude orchestrates it for me? (I'm asking strategically, I don't want you to launch the workflow yet.)
I'd like you to make a journal entry recording how this multi-agent setup works, the rules roles and responsibilities.
